mosaic
Class MosaicGenerator

java.lang.Object
  mosaic.MosaicGenerator

public class MosaicGenerator
extends java.lang.Object

OVERVIEW: Generates a series of mosaics with various resolutions (tile sizes) and color palettes. The mosaics are then stitched together into one composite mosaic. See the samples directory for examples. By default, the colors used in the image will be generated by the ImageBasedColorPaletteGenerator, which uses k-means clustering to select an optimal palette. You will need to include the Java Machine Learning (javaml) JAR that is included with this project. Other palette generators exist, such as the ManualColorPaletteGenerator, which allows the user to specify the colors to be used. USAGE: These public methods may be useful in integrating this library into an application - generateMosaic(BufferedImage, int, List) - Returns a single mosaic with specified width and colors. Useful if you plan to manipulate the image further. - generateCompositeMosaic(BufferedImage, List, List, ColorPaletteGenerator) - Returns an image containing all permutations of widths and color ranges. - run(String, String, List, List) - Generates and saves a composite image. Use this if you don't intend to further manipulate the image. - scaleImage(BufferedImage, int) - Scales an image back to specified size but will maintain the pixelated mosaic look.

Author:
alexroussos@gmail.com

MosaicGenerator

public MosaicGenerator()
Method Detail

run

public void run(java.lang.String inputUrl,
                java.lang.String outputDirectory,
                java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> colorCounts,
                java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> widths)
         throws java.net.MalformedURLException,
                java.io.IOException
Generate a composite of mosaics based on different color palettes and resolutions. NOTE: Depending on where images are hosted, they may be unreadable by ImageIO. Images hosted on Dropbox seem to work fine.

Parameters:
inputUrl - URL of image to be transformed into mosaic.
outputDirectory - Directory where composite image is to be saved. Defaults to "./generated_mosaics"
colorCounts - Number of colors to use in each mosaic (corresponds to rows in composite image) eg {8, 12, 24}
widths - The widths of each mosaic in pixels (corresponds to columns in composite image), eg {50, 100, 200}
Throws:
java.net.MalformedURLException
java.io.IOException

generateCompositeMosaic

public java.awt.image.BufferedImage generateCompositeMosaic(java.awt.image.BufferedImage sourceImage,
                                                            java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> colorCounts,
                                                            java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> widths,
                                                            ColorPaletteGenerator paletteGenerator)
Create a large image containing a mosaic for each permutation of number of colors and resolution. The smaller mosaics will be scaled up so that all are the same width as the largest.

Parameters:
sourceImage - Image from which to generate mosaics
colorCounts - List of how many colors to allow in each variation, eg {8, 16, 32}
widths - Resolution of each variation (height will be scaled to maintain aspect ratio), eg {50, 100, 200}
paletteGenerator - Provides the list of colors to allow in the mosaic
Returns:
Composite image

generateMosaic

public java.awt.image.BufferedImage generateMosaic(java.awt.image.BufferedImage sourceImage,
                                                   int width,
                                                   java.util.List<java.awt.Color> colors)
Generate a single mosaic (one resolution and color set). If the mosaic is too small, it can be scaled up using scaleImage(BufferedImage, int), which will maintain the pixelated mosaic look but result in a larger image that is more suitable for viewing.

Parameters:
sourceImage - Image from which to generate mosaic
width - How many tiles wide the mosaic will be
colors - Colors to use in the mosaic
Returns:

scaleImage

public java.awt.image.BufferedImage scaleImage(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image,
                                               int targetWidth)
Scale an image down to the specified width, maintaining the aspect ratio.
